now.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: They now live in the city centre.
There’s nothing I can do about this right now (=exactly now).
Please try to be more careful from now on (=starting from now).
There are a lot of bargains in the shops just now.
Sonia should have been home by now. Do you think she’s OK?
Until now, doctors have been able to do very little to treat this disease.
Just leave your shoes on the back porch for now.
now.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: The bell has rung – stop writing now.
If we leave now, we’ll be there before dark.
now.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: used when you know or understand something because of something you have just seen, just been told etc
now.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Having met the rest of the family, she now saw where he got his temper from.
now.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: used when getting someone’s attention before continuing what you are saying or changing the subject
now.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: Now, let’s move on to the question of payment.
now.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: used at the beginning of a sentence when asking for information
now.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: Now, what did you say your name was?
now.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: used when pausing when you are thinking what to say next
now.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: Now, let’s see, oh yes – they wanted to know what time you’ll be back on Friday.
now.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: used to say that if the situation was different, something different would happen
now.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: Now if I’d been in charge there’s no way I’d have let them use the van.
now.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: used to make someone calm, or comfort them when they are angry, upset etc
now.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: used when telling or reminding someone to do something
now.translation[0].definitions[8].exampl: Now hurry up! I haven’t got all day.
Don’t forget now, you have a dental appointment Thursday afternoon.
now.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: The population is much larger now than it used to be.
now – used when describing what a situation is like
Currently, the starting salary is around £20,000.
now – used when talking about a short period of time, after which the situation is likely to change
I think she’s at lunch at the moment – can I ask her to call you back?
At the moment I’m working in a restaurant, but I’m hoping to go to college.
now – used when you do not expect something that is true now to be permanent
Many areas are inaccessible at present due to heavy snow.
The official currency is the crown, presently about 30 to the dollar.
now – used when a situation is likely to change, especially because an arrangement is only temporary
You can stay here for the time being, until you find a flat.
now.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: because of something or as a result of something
now.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: Now that we know each other a little better, we get along fine.
I’m going to relax now the school year is over.
Now that I think of it, I acted the same way when I was his age.
